content:
My official placeholder tweet. Due to the increasing radicalization and erratic behavior of @elonmusk I am mostly off Twitter. I'm spending a lot more time on Mastadon and in other communities. I'll keep my profile updated.

I'll still check in and post, but not nearly as much.

https://t.co/N3Gx3VHYfZ

RT @mattjay: I really can't believe what @rmogull is doing over at Cloud SLAW (Security Lab A Week)

It feels like the best-kept secret in…

The 14th CloudSLAW just went out and early 2000 are following along! I'm so excited I even went and sponsored @daringfireball this week because I really believe free security training ANYONE can follow may really make a difference. https://t.co/TkwASqkEoo

I’m honored to say my name is finally being used in a targeting phishing attack!

No. I’m not emailing you for your phone number or anything else from Gmail.
https://t.co/7KFkQCKoIj

→ Following me @clintgibler for more security resources like this.

→ Joinin…

Really excited about my new side project- a free 15-30 minute cloud security lab delivered every week as a newsletter, blog, and YouTube video. 

https://t.co/2nNd5OwYaf

I’m not actively on Twitter anymore but you can hit me up on other platforms or email with questions!

@QuinnyPig @mattjay I won’t go there either. Or China (for the last 5 years or so) and a few other places. I’ve turned down some lucrative work opportunities. 

It matters.
https://t.co/OPVKaXYnUO

If you want to get the best prices on our @BlackHatEvents trainings they go up again soon. This year we updated our cloud IR class to have teams attack and respond against each other in “Adversarial Cloud Incident Response”

https://t.co/Eqkgsvw6Ve
Anyone here have a contact at Microsoft/Xbox trust and safety? A friend (in security had his son’s Xbox account compromised (looks Russian in origin based on the emails used).

https://t.co/WiXfHzccic

Plus- don’t forget to sign up for the RSA Disaster Recovery Breakfast!

Happy Friday! Want free CSPM for AWS? No limits on the number of accounts? No time limits? No forced up sell?

Yep. Done. Check it out-

https://t.co/HWtwS0DMkD

Migrated my Mastadon account to https://t.co/kM97k8yVGi. Looks like it went smooth and updated profile here so you can find me there. Chaos was a great starting home and donating as I move to an instance where I have more-direct involvement.
Just popping back into Twitter tk say hell yeah @apple! iCloud encryption for the win.
Just hoping in to say Mastadon now feels like 2008 Twitter… it’s nice. You should join us.
RT @expensivecare: My weekend read: American Sirens by @goes_by_hazzard. Enjoying it so far and haven’t even got to the history of #paramed…

My god, it’s full of stars…

@adamjodonnell @DennisF /me Raises hand
@swagitda_ The two are not mutually exclusive.

@randomuserid We were facing that decision on Mother’s Day during COVID when our cat (who was more like a dog) made the decision for us. Had a similar experience with our other cat a few years earlier (I left a family trip tk be home with her). Never gets easier.
@randomuserid I’m so sorry. Pets are family, full stop.

@Viss @tqbf Books? More like a Cohen brothers film. 

Although seems we are quickly careening into Tarantino territory…
I guess this is one way to make sure Trump never gets back on Twitter.

I’m in San Francisco for an Irish dance competition for the kids and it’s at the Marriott Marquis. I am… very disorientated and may have just pitched some random dance judges on the benefits of cloud automation her at the bar.
@BrianHonan I do work out… I suppose I have other viable assets.
https://t.co/W1fwQggS3K is now live.
Said it before, saying it again, awesome event!
@SecBarbie Fwd:cloudsec. Practitioners, defensive, technical, well run, totally built and run by the community
(Oh- I’m posting more on Mastadon than here these days but still using both)

@jjarava I was making bets. https://t.co/8uonn2qmxu is not federated. Closed system. https://t.co/95LDwIMToO is federated. Right now, chaos (and thus the wider Mastsdon ecosystem) is where more people moved so that’s where I’m focused.
@lexfri I had a friend who was republican when we met go canvas for the democrats this year. So maybe!

Now I don’t have to move! 

Time to start watering the plants again.

@fsmontenegro @dragosr I wouldn’t expect it to just die… but rot is the right word. And eventually, irrelevance. The story isn’t written yet- there’s still a chance it could survive and even thrive, but day after day it looks headed down the wrong path.

I’m happy to hang around and see what happens
@ChadWachs Rumor is some Mastadon instances will ban you for things like that.
Considering how many people around me are catching non-covid + sometimes covid… I’m back to masking a lot more after toning it down for a while.
@denalidevo Society isn’t real set up for it. Especially western societies.

@SecBarbie @elonmusk @Twitter We care but we don’t? Call it nostalgia for there was a time this was a great water cooler for all of us distributed around the world. Sometimes still is. But there will be other water coolers. 

Communities… find a way.
I’m guessing Elon was also using 2FA and now he can’t get back in to fix it himself like he planned.
@0x30n @davegraham I think I saw it’s back up now
@davegraham Possibly inadvertently ordered the shutdown of the microsoervice used for 2FA… so people can’t log back in now.

Wakanda Forever is a shining example of how a franchise can move forward after the loss of a cherished case member. Rise of Skywalker, while I don’t hate, is an example of how to fail in this endeavor.

@denalidevo Oh shit, I’m sorry!!!
@fsmontenegro It’s even a struggle at home now, and we aren’t making the kids wear them to school due to the other impacts on them. Of course they are all now sick with something other than covid.
@denalidevo I still wore them on planes/airports and places tightly packed with lower airflow, depending on local trends.
Mastsdon is nice and some great stuff over there, but I’ll miss Twitter when it finally collapses. Maybe it will survive in a usable form,  JT not betting on it.
Building a filter for emails that contain “just moving this to the top of your inbox” to send them straight to spam.

That’s today on Twitter.

I wonder how many feathers I’m rufflingby adding this to an industry standard:

“Do not attempt to support multi-cloud unless your organization is sufficiently mature within at least a single cloud provider and has appropriate staffing and tooling to support additional providers.
@bortels @sandycarielli Ouch.
@david_obrien That’s why I have to get it in writing!!!
@uptill_3 @QuinnyPig The full section lays out strategies and adoption patterns like primary/secondary as you describe. But that doesn’t fit in a tweet.

@anton_chuvakin This is the world we live in. 

Sadly.
@sandycarielli It’s usually some aspirational cost savings nonsense. Or to avoid lock-in, which happens anyway.
@sandycarielli Quite a bit actually. I run into it all the time. Various drivers, but most common are “cloud agnostic”, cost management (but it doesn’t work that way), or… developers asked for it.

@nojonesuk Totally. But at least I can provide security pros with a little job protection. 

It’s my version of a “business acceptance of risk” form for the masses.
Need to figure out why the audio is choppy but pretty pleased this came out so well. Was a rush job. https://t.co/5ZaK8je7pF
@snipeyhead Yep yep. I haven’t even had a weekend free for a while. But definitely need to get exactly the same cocktail after thanksgiving. Kinda wish it could be before.

It’s been a crappy day, but writing a CFP submission for a co-presentation with @Beaker was a delight. Laughing my ass off. Hopefully we write content that can keep up with the description (and get accepted).
@jcenters @BowTiedOx Nice job!
@jcfarris Now you’re just trying to get me cancelled!
Buying now. Maybe we’ll luck out and it won’t be an issue but not a risk I want to take. And I don’t even really have anything in DMs I’m worried about.
@HackingButLegal Oh yeah- I’m certain the data is still there someplace. My hope is it’s mostly a little more archived and harder to recover?
Oh wow- this is great!
@spy604 It amazes and amuses me when I hear people say that… and actually mean it! (Never a security pro, nearly always from the dev side)

I realized yesterday that when people ask me about my career my response should be 

“I stepped through the sliding doors”.

I always have a plan. I’m also always open to scrapping it.
@daveshackleford Our dining room table is covered with LEGO and @MarkRober builds, so our kids won’t even understand the concept.

Yesterday I learned from my middle school daughter than some kids being blood capsules to school to fake their death in a school shooting. A classmates had a couple break and ruin her backpack. 

More kids are dead today before I could even post this.

I’m considering building my first PC in decades… largely for VR gaming. For those of you that know way more than me is that still the right path or are pre-builts a better deal right now? Also… I figure an RTX 3080 Ti but Intel vs. Ryzen?

@bmastenbrook Got it, thanks
@bmastenbrook Thanks- so it won’t inhibit me on future upgrades

I’m not predicting Twitter’s collapse one way or the other, but like any disaster planning it’s worth knowing options.

Where are people headed next if there’s a meltdown? Countersocial? Back to blogs (I wish)? Somewhere else?
@dragosr @TProphet Thanks. Will check it out

@danielpunkass Same here. I miss that community
@spy604 I wish. After I retire maybe.

So yeah, seems to be like Twitter.
@keroz Problem is the way to communicate blogs and linkbacks/etc. has died off… hell, I used to do 3-5 posts a day + comments before Twitter
@froggynotacon @mhackling I think you can turn all that off with a few clicks. Or just use a mobile app. That’s the old Tweetdeck style and some people do like it (not me)
@danielcornell Cold Dan. Cold :)

@mhackling TikTok ain’t gonna happen for me until … the ownership issues are dealt with. Also have a foothold on https://t.co/EVnrPQTBXf but not really using it yet. Twitter could still come out of this okay
I should add- Slack/Discord might also be options, although I prefer the async Twitter model since I’m always bouncing around.
@skwashd HAHAHAHAHAHA

In response to @QuinnyPig I try to make AWS Permission Boundaries easier to understand, but I probably don’t. Tl;dr: if you want someone to admin some IAM in an account but not all the IAM, then you might need one: https://t.co/yC1kYWqUAH
@kennwhite @QuinnyPig I really try to minimize where I use them. They are a tool, not a toy, and once you add them tracking your real IAM posture gets harder. More crap to look at.
@kennwhite @QuinnyPig Unless you are delegating admin, you probably don’t need a permission boundary
I get to spend the weekend Cub Scout camping trip tethered to my Garmin satellite messenger in case… I’m sent places. Woo hoo!
@randwacker @HenryFollows Just our local camp- an easy weekend trip

Keep in mind if you are ever in a disaster:
1. Not everyone has resources to evacuate. If you stay, it takes resources from them. 
2. If you stay and need help it puts responders at risk.  
3. The sooner you move the more your options.
Say hello to Kyle. He’s a good egg  and important to follow if you do AWS stuff.

What do professional disaster responders do at a time like this?

Pack. Repack. Watch the weather. Get coverage at work. Some get pre-deployed to nearby safe zones and the track things to see where to roll out. 

Mostly planning and waiting to see where the need is.

@0xMatt Oh yeah! And movies and shows for the iPad/phone. 

Put things in plastic bags.
RT @Ugarles: you have to understand dosage. if a child eats a fistful of rainbow fentanyl, the child will become an addict; if a police off…

I will absolutely inspect every single piece of my children’s candy…

… to make sure I get my share of the good stuff.

@TeriRadichel I once spiked my feed with a custom headline that said “so and so is stealing my content”.  

Worked really well.
@ErrataRob Oh, that’s a long standing tradition. Also applies to French fries. And yes, I call it a tax.
Alrighty- looks like if I deploy it will be as a refill mission so… seems the odds are in favor of me making our family fall break trip next week. #selfishdisasterresponder
@jcenters Yup

@jcenters My threat model of most likely is something small limited to Europe; likely in-theater. 

I mean most likely is nothing at all.

@ErrataRob SpaceX has to meet shareholder expectations. NASA has to meet politician expectations, often to the compromise of engineering and procurement decisions. 

It’s all economics in the end.

@jcenters Just the iodide plus plans to seal home ventilation. Biggest risk scenario to me is something that has some particles blow over the ocean. So ride it out for the 39-ish days. More than that is less likely, and also much more intensive to plan for.

I was sad after spending the weekend with the mountain rescue team and knowing I don’t get to do that anymore. 

And yet I’m sitting here paranoid I’ll be deployed in the next week because I’m on-call for the hurricane and thus screw up a family trip and work. 

I’m complicated.

@matthbraun Oh, my gear bag is more of a disaster of a gear pile and I’m always scrambling last minute. We never know what we actually need and some stuff isn’t worth only having for disasters so I have to toss it in.
@matthbraun Tis a strange life we have chosen.
@fsmontenegro Thank you!

Airline: “You’ve been upgraded”

Me: “Woo hoo!”

Also me: “Crap, now I actually have to work on the flight”

Spent the weekend at the 75th Anniversary for the Rocky Mountain Rescue Group. I was on the team for 13 years.

Some team members going back to the 1950’s were there sharing stories. Absolutely incredible to hear that history first hand.

Also, mountain rescue is insane.
More like buying diapers for your kids 3 sizes too large. Technically you are meeting the objective, but in practice it… won’t really work out so well.
@david_obrien Hmm… curious where this is headed ;)

Is it possible…  just wait for it… normal consumers just like some Apple stuff and don’t buy things only out of brand loyalty?

Pro AWS Tip- AWS Security Hub will aggregate most other AWS security tool findings across regions and accounts… and then generate EventBridge events in that management account/region. This is rare behavior in AWS and provides a single point to siphon events.
@kmheintz @jeremiahg @taosecurity @Beaker @ryanaraine I always love it when actors are the real deal. Although then painful to watch Hollywood dumb down their skills.
The battery life on the #flipperzero is way better than I expected. So much to learn still to get the most out of this.
@CharlesDardaman I think the iPhone app might a little? The device itself… nope. No WiFi.

I’m getting very nervous I won’t be going to Disney on Fall break for the Halloween stuff with my family because I may be deployed. 

Yes, that’s selfish, but… there’s always a disaster to respond to. Just happens October is my month on rotation.
The only thing that causes as wide emotional swings as 3D printers are … children?
@mfratto Paper printers never give you the highs, just the lows

I did a bad thing and left out a major punchline- it isn’t just about ABAC, it’s about moving more access to Just in Time approvals, with attribute restrictions, and using out of band notifications/visibility.

@KiwiDrmr That’s why we moved it to CLI and ChatOps- it’s faster and easier than managing them via most other options I’ve seen.

@ryanaraine We don’t do that but I have a bit of sympathy. Now that I live on the vendor side, SSO nearly always requires much more support. It’s never as easy as it should be due to dealing with the identity provider side, even if you do a perfect job on the relying party side.

@ryanaraine Totally agree. I cringe when people get excited about physical MFA tokens. 

I also don’t think passwordless is going to save us here.

Weirdly- 20 years ago I wrote some of these concepts up for Gartner as something I called “Dynamic Trust”. It was WAY theoretical back then. But the cornerstones were Dynamic Authentication and Dynamic Authorization. I always thought we needed to split them better.
@ryanaraine I was trying to be nice and encouraging :)

MFA isn’t only awesome, it’s absolutely critical. But it also isn’t always enough (as we’ve seen lately). I wrote up how I like to layer in security to authorizations. It’s related to ABAC (and sometimes is ABAC) but we have new options now.

@daveshackleford You aren’t going to change your behavior. Most won’t, even if another catastrophe hits. I don’t think for a second I can change your mind.

@daveshackleford No, not feelings. Excess death rates are still high. Long COVID still increasing. No good options for immunocompromised. Measurable long term effects even in asymtomatic cases, which we don’t understand yet. Those are numbers, not feelings.

@daveshackleford I mean, I drop my masks a lot more than I used to, I also got infected and I worry about the long term consequences because I know the current science of this disease. That’s different from telling others to move on and celebrating low masking. You get that, right?

@daveshackleford @Dave_Maynor I get that, but maybe as a public health professional I also see that individual actions directly damage others. That’s why I keep pushing back. If it was just you hurting yourself that would be different

Our new IAM thing I’m excited about. Built for internal needs first, then converted to product. There will be a free tier once we finish with Early Access. Policy-based AWS JIT permissions via ChatOps with cool features like M of N and tag lockdowns: https://t.co/Ls90kGdM3y

@anton_chuvakin @taosecurity I’ve long used tourist… but I don’t like the derogatory nature. We have a massive knowledge and skills gap not due to lack of brains or experience, but because this stuff is so new still and it takes time to learn new fundamentals.

@taosecurity @anton_chuvakin Okay, that’s the difference. Big orgs with big budgets are rarely mature in cloud. Cloud native, to me, means native patterns, not just native tools. To be honest this would make a very interesting public debate/discussion … definitely needs more bandwidth than Twitter.
@taosecurity @anton_chuvakin I see the exact opposite- we likely have different definitions of mature and cloud native. I do see a lot of usage still for lift and shift.

New post on something I call the “AuthN/AuthZ Gap”. This is commonly known among IdM folks but I’ve found that a ton of security pros haven’t looked at it yet. Not a vuln, but bigger in cloud & something to know during control design and IR (containment).

https://t.co/M5UT3tGy5F
@mckeay Thanks- and yep, we see the same thing which is why we are releasing our Authorization Control product.

@anton_chuvakin @taosecurity I’m 12 years of cloud I totally agree that virtual security appliances are an anti pattern *if you fail to build using cloud native secure network patterns*. 

Even then, you still don’t usually need them. Sometimes you do, but in my experience around 80% can be dropped.

One of the biggest obstacles to many companies adopting AWS is Amazon competing in their markets. Retail, healthcare, etc. I hear it constantly and it’s been a boon for Microsoft.
What Microsoft needs is a Trustworthy Cloud Initiative. They have the people, the knowledge, and the tools.
@ma Yep… but TCI also impacted pretty much every product. Plus all the wraparound support on SDLC/threat modeling/etc. Again, from the outside, seems that isn’t keeping up.

I’ve been having some VERY uncomfortable discussions with orgs about Azure security lately. 

Microsoft has some of the best security pros out there, but they aren’t engaged in the right parts of Azure. It’s clear its a culture/process issue.

Customer pressure is only answer.

@CharlesDardaman Secure by design. Secure by default. Better internal processes and culture. I don’t know enough of the internal specifics, but have been told the preference is on speed vs. reliability and security.

@brownglock So that’s a misconfiguration, not necessarily an attack. Would you want to detect on making the bucket public? 

For the record I do consider a new misconfiguration a possible threat/attack… assume until otherwise proven to be a mistake.

I include, and encourage others to include, auditors in your threat models. Why? 90 day password rotations for users with MFA is really low on an attacker-based model, but a high threat in an audit. Same for most encryption. The list goes on…
